title-group.article-title: Effect of perioperative transdermal nicotine patch on postoperative pain: A systematic review and meta-analysis

sec.title: Background and Aims:
sec.p: Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) has emerged as a potential intervention for managing perioperative pain. However, their effectiveness remains unclear, as previous studies neither considered the effect of the route of administration nor differentiated the effect between smokers and non-smokers. This systematic review and meta-analysis aimed to determine the effect of a perioperative transdermal nicotine patch on postoperative pain in both smokers and non-smokers compared with a placebo.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: We performed a meta-analysis of randomised controlled trials (RCTs) comparing the effects of transdermal nicotine and placebo on postoperative pain. Databases of MEDLINE, EMBASE, CENTRAL, CINAHL, Google Scholar, Web of Science, and the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials were searched. This systematic review and meta-analysis followed the PRISMA guidelines. The findings were evaluated using forest plots and expressed as relative risk (RR) or mean difference (MD) for primary and secondary outcomes.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: Twelve studies included in the analysis showed no significant difference in pain scores (NRS) at 24 h between the two groups, with an MD −0.24 [95% confidence interval (CI): −0.55, 0.07; P = 0.13] (I2 = 77%, P < 0.00001), and there was no significant difference in postoperative opioid consumption (morphine equivalent) MD −0.92 (95% CI: −5.04, 3.21; P = 0.66) (I2 = 23%, P = 0.27). Similarly, the two groups had no significant differences in the time to first rescue analgesia, postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), or patient satisfaction. However, the required information size was not achieved for the outcomes of postoperative opioid requirement, reduction in postoperative pain, PONV, and the time for rescue analgesia.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: The perioperative transdermal nicotine patch did not significantly reduce postoperative pain scores compared with placebo. There appears to be a significant reduction in smokers, but the evidence is inadequate to conclude this finding.

sec.title: INTRODUCTION
sec.p: Effective management of postoperative pain is a crucial element of enhanced recovery protocols and is closely linked to improved surgical outcomes, reduced morbidity, and decreased duration of hospital stays.[12] Although opioids are commonly employed for moderate to severe postoperative pain, concerns about their adverse effects and the potential for long-term dependence have heightened interest in multimodal analgesia strategies aimed at minimising opioid use.[34]

Nicotine replacement therapy (NRT) has emerged as a potential intervention for managing perioperative pain, offering a novel approach to pain relief.[5] Nicotine acts as a full agonist on nicotinic acetylcholine receptors in both the autonomic and central nervous systems, exhibiting stimulatory properties.[6]

The perioperative period offers a crucial opportunity for both smoking cessation and pain management through the use of NRT. A comprehensive understanding of how NRT affects postoperative pain and analgesic requirements could enhance perioperative care for both smokers and non-smokers. The analgesic response to nicotine may vary between these groups. Chronic nicotine exposure in smokers can lead to neuroadaptive changes, potentially altering pain perception and response to analgesics.[7] Evidence indicates that smokers may experience higher baseline pain levels and increased postoperative pain compared to non-smokers.[8]

Individual studies have reported conflicting outcomes, with some suggesting analgesic benefits while others indicate no effect or potential harm. A rigorous synthesis of these findings is necessary to clarify the clinical relevance of NRT in surgical patients.

The efficacy of transdermal nicotine therapy remains uncertain, as previous meta-analyses did not account for the impact of the administration route[9] nor did they distinguish between the effects on smokers and non-smokers.[10] This systematic review and meta-analysis seeks to evaluate the impact of a perioperative transdermal nicotine patch on postoperative pain in both smokers and non-smokers, compared to a placebo. The primary objective was to assess the impact of transdermal nicotine compared to a placebo on postoperative pain, measured using the Numerical Rating Scale (NRS), at 24 h postoperatively. Secondary objectives include evaluating postoperative opioid consumption, time to first rescue analgesia, incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting (PONV), and patient satisfaction.

sec.title: METHODS
sec.p: This systematic review and meta-analysis followed the guidelines outlined in the Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic Reviews and Meta-Analyses (PRISMA) guidelines.[11] The review was registered propsectively with the International Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews PROSPERO (ID: CRD42024497363).

sec.title: Literature search
sec.p: We conducted a comprehensive search of articles in Medline (PubMed), Ovid (Embase), the Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials (CENTRAL), and CINAHL. Additionally, we performed manual searches using Google Scholar and ResearchGate. We employed a mix of controlled vocabulary terms and free keywords: ‘Transdermal nicotine’ OR ‘Nicotine replacement therapy’ AND ‘postoperative pain’ OR ‘Pain’ OR ‘Analgesia’ [Supplementary Table 1]. There were no restrictions on the publication year. The search was conducted up to November 2024. Moreover, we reviewed references from pertinent studies and review articles to find potential additions to our analysis.

sec.p: We employed the PICO framework to organise our findings. The patient population included adults over 18 years undergoing surgical procedures. The intervention received was transdermal NRT, which was compared to standard postoperative pain management protocols that did not include NRT. The outcomes assessed included the postoperative pain score (NRS) at 24 h, the time to first rescue analgesia, postoperative opioid consumption, the incidence of PONV, and patient satisfaction.

sec.title: Eligibility criteria
sec.p: Randomised controlled trials (RCTs) and controlled cohort studies assessing the impact of transdermal nicotine compared with placebo on postoperative pain in patients undergoing surgery were included. The exclusion criteria included case reports, editorials, expert opinions, and studies in languages other than English. Studies administering nicotine via routes other than the transdermal route were excluded.

sec.title: Study selection
sec.p: Two reviewers, BY and AM, independently examined the titles and abstracts identified through the literature search. Full-text versions of all citations that might meet the eligibility criteria were obtained and assessed for possible inclusion. Any disagreements about inclusion were resolved through discussion with a third reviewer, PK.

sec.title: Data extraction
sec.p: A standardised form for data extraction was created in Microsoft Excel by the reviewer (BY). The extraction process was carried out by BY and MG, with BG verifying the results. This form collected details on smoking status during the publication year, the use of intraoperative analgesics, the dosage and duration of NRT, pain scores, and the incidence of PONV within 24 h. If additional information was needed, the study authors were contacted.

Two independent reviewers, BY and DL, assessed the bias in the included trials using the Cochrane Collaboration Risk of Bias 2.0 tool.[12] The risk was classified as low, unclear, or high across several domains, such as deviations from the intervention, missing outcome data, outcome measurement, result selection, and overall bias. A third author, PK, settled any disagreements.

All seven authors evaluated the quality of evidence using the Grades of Recommendation, Assessment, Development, and Evaluation (GRADE) system.[13] The strength of the evidence was classified as high, moderate, low, or very low quality. Any differences were resolved through consensus.

sec.title: Primary and secondary outcomes
sec.p: The primary outcome was the postoperative pain score, measured using the NRS, at 24 h. The secondary outcomes included postoperative opioid consumption, time to first rescue analgesia, incidence of PONV, and patient satisfaction.

For dichotomous variables, such as the incidence of PONV, the risk ratio (RR) with a 95% confidence interval (CI) was employed. Continuous variables, including postoperative pain scores, time to first rescue analgesia, postoperative opioid consumption, and patient satisfaction, were expressed as mean differences (MD) with corresponding 95% CI. Significance was set at P < 0.05, and the data in the form of median and interquartile range were converted into estimated mean and standard deviation (SD) using the methods of Wan et al.[14] and Luo et al.[15] Heterogeneity was assessed using I² statistics. We used a random-effects model analysis. Subgroup analysis was performed for the outcome of postoperative pain NRS at 24 h, including smokers alone.

The findings were evaluated using forest plots and expressed as relative risk (RR) or MD for both primary and secondary outcomes. A funnel plot was utilised to assess publication bias in the meta-analysis, and Review Manager 5.4 was employed for the statistical analysis.

We utilised Trial Sequential Analysis Software 0.9.5.5 Beta (Copenhagen Trial Unit, Copenhagen, Denmark) to perform trial sequential analyses, aiming to assess the impact of perioperative transdermal nicotine patches on postoperative pain. To minimise the probability of type-1 errors, the Z-value thresholds were adjusted using the O’Brien–Fleming pending function, which reinstated the intended maximum risk. The crossing of the Z-curve over the O’Brien–Fleming α-spending boundaries signified statistical significance. To address the risk of type-2 errors, the β-spending function and futility boundaries were applied. When interventions did not show a difference beyond the anticipated effect, they crossed the futility boundaries. The calculation of information size considered low-bias studies, incorporating a 5% type-1 error risk and 95% power.

sec.title: RESULTS
sec.p: This review included 12 RCTs[161718192021222324252627] of 312 screened publications [Figure 1, Table 1]. Among these, seven trials[161718212327] raised some concerns regarding the risk of bias [Figure 2].

sec.p: The surgical procedures undertaken comprised abdominal surgeries,[1618192021242526] thoracotomy,[22] lumbar disc surgery,[16] arthroscopic shoulder surgery,[26] and molar extraction.[22]
Seven studies included participants of both genders,[17202122252627] Four studies included only male participants,[16181923] and one study included only female participants.[24]

Two studies focused exclusively on smokers,[1925] while seven studies concentrated solely on non-smokers.[17182022232426] Additionally, one study included both groups.[16] Two studies (Martins Filho et al.[21] and Malaithong et al.[27]) did not disclose the smoking status of participants.
The transdermal nicotine dosage administered varied from 7 to 21 mg per 24h period, and a high dose of 21–42 mg was administered contingent upon the number of cigarettes smoked by Zhu et al.[19]

The timing of insertion was immediately before anaesthesia induction in three studies[202327] 1 h before induction in six studies,[161821222526] 2 h before induction in two studies,[1724] and on the day of admission in one study.[19]

Intraoperative analgesia was administered through various methods, including intravenous fentanyl infusion,[171826] fentanyl bolus,[21232425] morphine bolus,[162025] and remifentanil infusion.[19] Postoperative analgesia was managed using several approaches, such as patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) with morphine,[161718202527] morphine bolus,[20] sufentanil infusion.[18] thoracic epidural analgesia (TEA),[22] and meperidine.[2426]

sec.title: Postoperative pain score (NRS) at 24 hours
sec.p: Ten studies[16181920212223252627] with 645 patients were included in both groups (NRT group and Placebo group) i.e. intervention and comparator group. They showed no significant difference in pain scores (NRS) at 24 h between the two groups, with an MD 0.25 (95% CI: −0.56, 0.06; P = 0.12) (I2 = 78%, P < 0.00001) [Figure 3a].

sec.p: The required information size needed to achieve a 95% power, based on the reduction in pain score by 1 at 24 h, was 452 [Supplementary Figure 1].

Subgroup analysis, focusing solely on smokers in two studies,[1925] revealed a significant reduction in postoperative pain scores (NRS) at 24 h with MD −0.56 (95% CI: −0.62, 0.51; P < 0.00001), with no heterogeneity between the studies (I2 = 0%, P = 0.54) [Figure 3a].
For smokers, the required information size, estimated for a power of 95% based on a reduction in pain score by 1 at 24 h, was 117 [Supplementary Figure 2].

In contrast, subgroup analysis of non-smokers across five studies[1820222326] showed no significant difference between the two groups, with MD −0.25 (95% CI: −0.74, 0.23; P = 0.31) (I2 = 65%, P = 0.31) [Figure 3a].

sec.title: Postoperative opioid consumption
sec.p: A total of 287 patients from five studies[1618202527] that were compared for postoperative opioid consumption showed no discernible difference in opioid (morphine equivalent) consumption, with a MD −0.92 (95% CI: −5.04, 3.21; P = 0.66), with low heterogeneity between the studies (I2 = 23%, P = 0.27) [Figure 3b].
The required information size needed to achieve a 95% power, based on the postoperative opioid reduction of 6 mg morphine equivalent was 470 [Supplementary Figure 3].

sec.title: Time to first rescue analgesia
sec.p: Two studies[1724] assessed for time to first rescue analgesia, with 90 patients in both groups. There was no significant difference between the two groups, with an MD 94.88 minutes (95% CI: −73.19, 262.94; P = 0.27), with significant heterogeneity between the studies (I2 = 100%, P < 0.00001) [Figure 4a]. The wide CI indicates insufficient data to draw a definitive conclusion about this particular outcome.

caption.p: (a) Time to first rescue analgesia in minutes. (b) Incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting. (c) Patient satisfaction. SD=Standard Deviation, CI=Confidence Interval, IV=Inverse Variance

sec.p: The required information size needed to achieve a 95% power for the prolongation of rescue analgesia by 90 min was 593 [Supplementary Figure 4].

sec.title: Incidence of postoperative nausea and vomiting
sec.p: Nine studies[161718192021242526] presented data on the incidence of PONV, including 551 patients in both groups. The pooled data showed no significant difference in the incidence of PONV between the two groups (RR: 1.09; 95% CI: 0.75, 1.61; P = 0.65), with considerable heterogeneity between the studies (I2 = 70%, P = 0.0009) [Figure 4b].
The required information size needed to achieve a 95% power, based on a 20% reduction of PONV, was 2894 for the overall population [Supplementary Figure 5].

sec.title: Patient satisfaction
sec.p: Data on patient satisfaction were provided in two trials.[1617] With 135 patients, they revealed no significant difference between the groups, with a pooled MD 7.37 (95% CI: −5.36, 20.11; P = 0.26) and considerable heterogeneity between the studies (I2 = 96%, P < 0.00001) [Figure 4c].

sec.title: Quality of evidence
sec.p: The quality of evidence on the effect of NRT on postoperative pain was very low [Table 2].

sec.title: Trial sequential analysis
sec.p: The required information size needed to achieve a 95% power, based on the reduction in pain score by 1 at 24 h, postoperative opioid reduction of 6 mg morphine equivalent, and 20% reduction of PONV were 452, 470, and 2894 for the overall population, and the sample size in the current analysis were 645, 287, and 551, respectively.

Among smokers, the required information size was estimated for a power of 95% based on the reduction in pain score by 1 at 24 h, and the prolongation of rescue analgesia by 90 min. The required information sizes were 117 and 593, and the sample sizes in the current analysis were 129 and 90, respectively.

Thus, further studies are required to generate conclusive evidence on the impact on postoperative opioid requirement, PONV, and the time to rescue analgesia, as the necessary information size has not been achieved [Supplementary Figures 1–5].

sec.title: Publication bias
sec.p: To assess publication bias for the primary outcome of postoperative pain at 24 h, a funnel plot was used [Supplementary Figure 6].

sec.title: DISCUSSION
sec.p: This meta-analysis demonstrated that the administration of therapeutic nicotine through the transdermal route is associated with no significant reduction in postoperative pain scores at 24 h post-surgery, without any significant difference in postoperative opioid consumption, time to first rescue analgesia, incidence of PONV, and patient satisfaction compared with placebo.

The analgesic properties of nicotine were initially demonstrated by Pollock LJ et al. in a feline model of visceral pain,[28] which is believed to be mediated by the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (nAChR) a pentameric ligand-gated ion channels, formed by a combination of subunits (α 1-10, β 1-4, γ, δ, ɛ)[629] and primarily through the α4β2 subunit.[3031] Activation of this receptor subunit stimulates the release of spinal norepinephrine, and the administration of the nAChR antagonist mecamylamine was found to attenuate the analgesic effects of nicotine in mice,[3233] while other mechanisms involving antagonism at the α9/10 subunit[34] and action on the μ receptor[35] and α7 prolong the analgesic effect of nicotine.[3035] Additionally, mediated through its anti-inflammatory properties[3637] and endogenous opioid peptides, it produces analgesic effects.[38]

A previous meta-analysis[9] that showed no statistically significant benefit in perioperative analgesia did not consider the effect of the route of administration; it included both intranasal and transdermal routes, where the peak serum nicotine concentrations differ. In contrast, the current analysis included only transdermal nicotine alone where the peak plasma concentration was achieved between 150 and 210 min after the application of the patch,[3940] and the active principle was absorbed gradually over 24 hours, resulting in less variability in plasma nicotine levels[4142] and a stable serum concentration with acceptable inter-patient variability;[43] in addition, the cumulative analgesic effect seems to persist for up to 80 h.[23]

There exist disparities between genders, as male individuals exhibit an elevated pain tolerance upon application of transdermal nicotine patches, whereas such an effect is not observed in females.[444546] Three studies in our analysis which were done on males alone showed a benefit of NRT in all. These differences in pain thresholds between both genders can be due to pain response modulation by oestrogen.[47]

In smokers, abstinence during the perioperative period demonstrated a significant increase in pain sensitivity compared to non-deprived or non-smokers, due to the upregulation of α4β2 receptors and a sudden increase in unbound nAChR.[4849] In our analysis, two studies[1925] included smokers alone, and one study[25] indicated no notable advantage, but it involved a small sample size and a lower dose of NRT. The other study’s[19] dosing was based on tobacco use and dependence guidelines,[50] which propose an initial transdermal nicotine replacement dose of 21 mg daily for individuals who smoke ≤20 cigarettes per day and 42 mg for individuals who smoke >20 cigarettes per day; even the 21 mg patch was discovered to only replace about half of the baseline serum nicotine levels in these smokers. Consequently, higher doses of nicotine patches may be necessary for acute abstinent smokers to assess the effectiveness of NRT in addressing nicotine withdrawal-related pain sensitivity changes. Restoring nicotine at a level equivalent to regular smoking exposure in smoking-abstinent patients led to a decrease in postoperative pain and opioid consumption. Thus, smokers need higher perioperative dosing of NRT based on the number of cigarettes smoked to combat the changes in pain sensitivity associated with nicotine withdrawal.

Even though the subgroup of smokers showed a significant decrease in postoperative pain, opioid consumption in this subgroup was demonstrated by only one study,[25] which showed no significant difference.

Few studies[51525354] demonstrated that smokers were less likely to suffer from PONV than non-smokers. Consequently, the perioperative use of nicotine as a prophylactic measure for PONV was explored. Ionesu et al.[55] demonstrated a significant reduction in the incidence of PONV in patients receiving NRT. Later, Czanrnetzki et al.[56] showed no significant difference; instead, patients receiving NRT had an earlier incidence of PONV. In our analysis, four studies[17192526] showed benefits, four studies[16182024] showed disadvantage, and one study[21] showed no difference, with an overall pooled result of no significant difference between the two. The mechanism is thought to be mediated through inhibition of receptors mediated in PONV, such as D2, 5HT3, and histamine,[54] and smoking increases the metabolism of drugs (including anaesthetics responsible for PONV) by increasing CYTP450;[57] In addition, nicotine also increases GI stimulation (motility).[54] However, two studies[1926] among the four[17192526] that showed benefit used total intravenous anaesthesia, which can be confounding.

This study has several limitations. The included studies used the NRS tool as a measurement of analgesia, which is subjective instead of morphine equivalent, and included different types of surgery, as nicotine has variable antinociceptive properties in somatic and visceral pain,[5859] encompassing both sex and using different doses of NRT in different studies. In addition, serum nicotine levels were not measured, and no dose-response relationship was investigated. No standard anaesthesia protocol was followed, as volatile anaesthetic agents were believed to be nicotinic antagonists,[606162] and there was significant heterogeneity across the studies. Additionally, the haemodynamic variables were not examined.

sec.title: CONCLUSION
sec.p: The perioperative transdermal nicotine patch did not demonstrate a significant reduction in postoperative pain scores, time to first rescue analgesia, incidence of postoperative nausea vomiting, or patient satisfaction compared with placebo. It appears that there is a significant reduction in smokers, but the evidence is inadequate to conclude this finding.
